line: Sample Format For Reviewing A Journal Article
label: heading

line: R eading and summarizing a research article in the behavioral or medical sciences can be overwhelming.
label: paragraph

line: Below is a simple model to guide students through this process.
label: paragraph

line: Authors’ last names (year) conducted a study about ________________________. The
label: paragraph

line: participants were/the setting was ___________________________. (New paragraph) The findings
label: paragraph

line: were _____________________________. Discussion. (Possibly a new paragraph) The authors
label: paragraph

line: suggested _____________________. Discussion.
label: paragraph

line: Students should fill in the blanks with their own words.
label: paragraph

line: comprehension and may also be considered plagiarism.
label: paragraph

line: To copy directly from the article fails to show
label: paragraph

line: To “fill in the blanks”, a student should read the journal article and pay specific attention to:
label: heading

line: Sentence #1- Authors’ last names (year) conducted a study about _________________.
label: heading

line: Read the Abstract; this will give an overview of the study’s (article’s) purpose.
label: paragraph

line: Read the entire article without trying to summarize it.
label: paragraph

line: Go back and read the Literature Review or Background section of the article. Toward the end of
label: paragraph

line: the section, the authors should identify gaps in the existing literature and tell the reader how the
label: paragraph

line: current study will fill that gap. The authors will also state their hypothesis (purpose) at the end of
label: paragraph

line: this section.
label: paragraph

line: Section #2 - The participants were/the setting was ___________________________.
label: heading

line: Read the Methods section of the paper. In this section, the authors will describe how the data was
label: paragraph

line: collected, who was included in the sample, and any instruments used.
label: paragraph

line: A reader might want to consider sample size, demographic characteristics, or any interesting
label: paragraph

line: protocol.
label: paragraph

line: It is not necessary to report every fact (i.e., 35% of the participants were male, 71% identified
label: paragraph

line: their race as Asian).
label: paragraph

line: Section #3 - The findings were _____________________________.
label: heading

line: Read the Findings section of the article.
label: paragraph

line: Some statistics may be confusing. Pay attention to key words such as “increased”, “decreased”,
label: paragraph

line: “improved”, and “reduced”.
label: paragraph

line: “No change” may also be considered a significant finding.
label: paragraph

line: Next, read the Discussion section. The authors will present the findings in general terms.
label: paragraph

line: Section #4 - The authors suggested _____________________.
label: heading

line: Read the Discussion section and look for comments that the authors made about the intervention
label: paragraph

line: or program such as “Did it work?” or “Should it be continued?”.
label: paragraph

line: Look for the author’s critique of why the study did or did not produce results. Did anything
label: paragraph

line: unexpected influence the findings?
label: paragraph

line: The author may suggest a future line of research or “next steps” to improve the body of
label: paragraph

line: knowledge.
label: paragraph

line: Sample format, Page 1 of 2
label: paragraph

line: Additional Considerations:
label: heading

line: A literature review is a summary of what research has been completed in a topic area; it should be
label: paragraph

line: summarized in your own words.
label: paragraph

line: Read the entire article first and then go back and take notes. Jot down notes in your own words.
label: paragraph

line: This increases comprehension as well as decreases the likelihood of plagiarism.
label: paragraph

line: The review is written in third person; no “I” or “you”.
label: paragraph

line: Unless stated otherwise, a literature review ideally reflects articles published in the last five to ten
label: paragraph

line: years.
label: paragraph

line: Not every detail or fact needs to be reported. A reader will obtain a copy of the article if more
label: paragraph

line: information is needed.
label: paragraph

line: Write the literature review in the past tense; the research has already been completed.
label: paragraph

line: The article cannot “do”, “find”, or “say” anything. The authors are the people who conducted the
label: paragraph

line: study.
label: paragraph

line: The above format is a guideline. It may be necessary to change the verbs or to expand an idea.
label: paragraph

line: Sample format, Page 2 of 2
label: paragraph
